expectations:
- MUST be in Latin American Spanish

      
  # How to evaluate

  You are evaluating a CURRICULUM, not a glossary. Think like a curriculum designer reviewing a colleague's work — use domain expertise and professional judgment, not mechanical rule-checking.

  ## Structure

  Output is organized into LESSON UNITS (thematic groups) containing CONCEPTS (individual teachable items).
  - Each concept should be a single, specific idea — something a domain expert would consider one teachable unit
  - Lesson sizes should be 3-8 concepts and should vary naturally across lessons
  - Total concept coverage should be exhaustive for the chapter's scope

  ## Evaluating concept quality

  Ask: "Is this ONE teachable thing, or is it secretly a bundle of separate things?"
  - A concept is too broad only if it genuinely bundles multiple DISTINCT teachable items that a student would need separate lessons for
  - Use domain expertise: terms that sound broad to a generalist may be a single well-defined concept in the field
  - Conjunctions (AND/OR/VS and equivalents in any language) signal potential broadness, but only penalize when they join genuinely separate topics — not when the comparison itself IS the concept, or when "and" connects an entity to its work
  - Concept titles should be concrete and self-explanatory, not interpretive thesis statements or vague abstractions

  ## Evaluating scope

  The chapter description is the SOURCE OF TRUTH. Neighboring chapters are guardrails against scope creep, not vetoes.

  The key principle: **judge by framing, not by keywords.** A concept belongs in THIS chapter if its primary teaching purpose serves THIS chapter's learning goals — even if the concept mentions words that appear in a neighboring chapter's title. Ask: "What is this concept primarily TEACHING?" not "Does this concept MENTION a neighboring topic?"

  When in doubt, favor the chapter description. If a concept is framed through this chapter's lens and serves its learning goals, it is in-scope.

  ## Evaluating lesson quality

  - Lesson descriptions should be concise and go straight to the content — no filler words like "introduces", "presents", "teaches", "explores"
  - Logical progression from foundational to advanced
  - No summary, review, or assessment lessons
  - Should follow the specified language (proper nouns and established technical terms may remain in their original language)

  ## Coverage

  Completeness is the key metric. Are all topics in the chapter description covered with sufficient granularity? Don't penalize for fewer concepts if the chapter's scope is inherently narrow.

  ## Proportionality

  Weight your scoring proportionally. A curriculum that covers the chapter exhaustively with good structure but has a few overly-broad concept titles is fundamentally different from one that misses entire topics or systematically violates scope. Minor title-phrasing issues should not dominate the score when the overall curriculum quality is strong.

rankings.reasoning: Model B provides the most exhaustive and granular coverage of the chapter. It has 26 lessons with approximately 200 concepts, covering every topic in the chapter description thoroughly: carbonyl structure, addition mechanisms, enol/enolate chemistry, aldol, Claisen, Michael, selectivity control, stereochemistry, silyl enol ethers, organocatalysis, and 1,3-dicarbonyl chemistry. Concept granularity is excellent — most concepts are single teachable ideas. Lesson sizes vary naturally (5-8 concepts). The progression is logical from fundamentals to advanced selectivity topics. There are a few minor issues: some concept titles could be slightly more specific (e.g., 'Aldolación' is a bit bare), and a couple of concepts like 'Comparación de reactividad aldehído cetona' uses a comparison structure that borders on violating the no-comparison rule. The organocatalysis lesson and some stereochemistry concepts are well-placed within the chapter scope. Lesson descriptions mostly avoid forbidden words. The neighboring chapter filtering is well done — no obvious overlap with acid derivatives, aromatics, or other neighboring chapters. Some concepts about acylation via enolates could border on the 'ácidos carboxílicos y derivados' chapter, but they're framed through the enolate lens. Overall, this is the most complete and well-structured curriculum.

Model E provides very good coverage with 28 lessons and approximately 170 concepts. Granularity is strong — concepts are well-scoped single ideas. The curriculum covers all major topics: carbonyl structure, hydration, reductions with hydrides, organometallics, facial selectivity, cyanohydrins, acetals, thioacetals, imines/enamines, keto-enol tautomerism, enolates (kinetic/thermodynamic separately), halogenation, aldol (base-catalyzed, condensation, crossed, intramolecular, stereochemistry separately), Claisen, Michael, Robinson annulation, and chemoselectivity. The separation of kinetic and thermodynamic enolates into separate lessons is pedagogically sound. Some minor issues: the reduction lesson with hydrides (NaBH4, LiAlH4) could be seen as borderline overlap with a general transformations chapter, but it's framed as carbonyl chemistry. Thioacetals lesson has only 5 concepts which is fine. The chemoselectivity lesson at the end is a good addition. Lesson descriptions are mostly clean though a few could be tighter. A couple of concept titles use commas to join items (e.g., 'Iminas, iminios, enaminas' as a lesson title is fine). Good neighboring chapter awareness. Slightly less organized than Model B in some areas but very thorough.

Model D has 20 lessons with approximately 130 concepts. Coverage is quite comprehensive, hitting all major chapter topics. It includes malonic/acetoacetic ester synthesis which is a nice addition. Granularity is generally good, though some concepts are slightly broad: 'Diferencias entre aldehídos y cetonas' could be split, 'Equivalentes sintéticos de enolato' as a concept title within its own lesson is somewhat redundant, and 'Estereocontrol en la reacción aldólica (modelos syn/anti)' bundles multiple ideas. Some concept titles use 'vs.' (e.g., 'Enolatos cinéticos vs. enolatos termodinámicos', 'Alquilación en carbono vs. alquilación en oxígeno', 'Nucleófilos duros vs. blandos en adición conjugada') which violates the prompt rules. The reductions/oxidations lesson could be seen as scope creep since the chapter is about nucleophilic addition and enolate chemistry specifically, not redox. Overall solid structure with logical progression. Lesson descriptions are clean. Some neighboring chapter boundary issues with oxidation reactions.

Model A has 9 lessons with approximately 63 concepts. While the concepts are well-scoped individually and the organization is logical, the coverage is notably less exhaustive than the top models. It covers the main topics (carbonyl properties, O-nucleophile additions, N-nucleophile additions, C-nucleophile additions, enol tautomerism, enolate generation, aldol, Claisen, Michael) but misses several important subtopics: no stereochemistry of aldol (Zimmerman-Traxler), no crossed aldol strategies in detail, no Mukaiyama aldol, no silyl enol ethers, no malonic/acetoacetic ester synthesis, no 1,3-dicarbonyl chemistry in depth, no facial selectivity, limited selectivity control discussion. The Robinson annulation is mentioned only as 'Secuencia en tándem de Robinson' which is vague. Concept titles are generally clean and follow the rules well. Lesson descriptions are good. The curriculum feels like a solid outline but not exhaustive as required. For a chapter with this much content, 63 concepts is insufficient.

Model F has 16 lessons with approximately 130 concepts. Coverage is broad, including some topics not explicitly in the chapter description (Reformatsky, Knoevenagel, Mannich, Cannizzaro, Tischenko, Baeyer-Villiger, umpolung/Corey-Seebach, retrosynthetic analysis). While some of these are relevant to carbonyl chemistry broadly, several represent scope creep: Baeyer-Villiger is an oxidation reaction that could belong in acid derivatives, Cannizzaro and Tischenko are niche, and the retrosynthetic analysis lesson feels like a meta-skill lesson which the prompt says to avoid. The 'Adiciones con Nucleófilos de Heteroátomo' lesson has 12 concepts, violating the 8-concept maximum. Several concept titles use 'vs.' (e.g., 'Adición 1,2 vs. adición 1,4', 'Wittig estabilizado vs. no estabilizado', 'Control termodinámico vs. cinético'). Some lesson titles use colons with subtitles which is acceptable but wordy. The nomenclature concepts ('Aldehídos: estructura y nomenclatura', 'Cetonas: estructura y nomenclatura') could overlap with a general organic chemistry naming chapter. The NaBH4/LiAlH4 reductions are included which could be scope creep. Overall decent but with notable rule violations and scope issues.

Model C has 10 lessons but the first lesson has only 1 concept ('Polarización del enlace carbonilo C=O'), which violates the minimum of 3 concepts per lesson. Several concept titles are excessively long and read like descriptions rather than glossary entries: 'Mecanismo general de adición nucleofílica a carbonilos (ataque → tetraédrico → protonación)', 'Adición de organometálicos a carbonilos (formación de alcoholes tras protonación)', 'Condiciones para obtener enolato cinético (base fuerte, baja T, sustrato impedido)'. Multiple concepts use parenthetical explanations which makes them verbose. Some concepts bundle multiple ideas: 'Halogenación α de enolatos (base y ácido)' combines two separate conditions. The total number of concepts (~60) is insufficient for exhaustive coverage of this chapter. Missing topics include: Wittig reaction, thioacetals, detailed aldol stereochemistry treatment, silyl enol ethers as a separate topic, haloform reaction, Robinson annulation detail, and more. Lesson descriptions sometimes start with forbidden words. The curriculum feels incomplete and violates several formatting rules.

Model G has only 10 lessons with approximately 56 concepts. This is the least exhaustive output. Many concepts are too broad: 'Estructura del enol', 'Estructura del enolato' could be broken down further. Coverage gaps are significant: no Mukaiyama aldol, no silyl enol ethers, no stereochemistry of aldol (Zimmerman-Traxler), no facial selectivity, no 1,3-dicarbonyl chemistry, no malonic/acetoacetic ester synthesis, minimal selectivity control discussion. The Wolff-Kishner reduction in the nitrogen nucleophiles lesson is scope creep (it's a reduction, not really about N-nucleophile addition to carbonyls in the context of this chapter). 'Alfa-halogenación de ácidos carboxílicos' likely belongs in the neighboring 'Ácidos carboxílicos y derivados' chapter. Some lessons have only 5 concepts which is acceptable but feels thin. The Robinson annulation is mentioned but with minimal detail. Overall, this curriculum is too sparse for exhaustive coverage of a chapter on carbonyls and enolates.

Model A followed every single instruction perfectly. The concepts are extremely granular and specific, completely avoiding the forbidden conjunctions ('y', 'o', 'vs.'). The lesson sizes naturally vary between 5 and 8 concepts, adhering to the sizing rule. The lesson descriptions go straight to the point without using forbidden introductory words. The coverage is exhaustive and stays strictly within the boundaries of the chapter without overlapping into neighboring chapters. An exceptional output.

Model E provided a masterclass in granular curriculum design. It took the instruction to 'add as many concepts as needed' and 'break down topics into their smallest logical units' to heart, producing 28 highly detailed lessons. It flawlessly executed the negative constraints: no compound concepts (no 'y', 'o', 'vs.'), no forbidden verbs in descriptions, and strict adherence to the chapter's scope without hallucinating into adjacent chapters. The lesson sizes vary naturally. A phenomenal and truly exhaustive output.

Model B provides excellent content and mostly respects the concept granularity rules (avoiding 'y' and 'vs.' by using spaces, which is clunky but acceptable). However, it blatantly violates a specific formatting rule: 'Don't force every lesson to the same size' and 'Do lesson sizes vary naturally, or are they all the same number?'. Model B generated 26 lessons and rigidly forced exactly 8 concepts into every single one of them. This is a significant structural penalty, but the content quality keeps the score relatively high.

Model G is well-structured and mostly avoids compound concept titles (the 'y' in 'hidruro de litio y aluminio' is acceptable as it is a chemical name). The lesson sizes vary naturally. However, it failed the neighboring chapter constraint by including 'Alfa-halogenación de ácidos carboxílicos' (Hell-Volhard-Zelinsky reaction), which belongs in the neighboring 'Ácidos carboxílicos y derivados' chapter. Its coverage is also slightly less exhaustive than the top models.

Model C failed the most critical rule regarding concept granularity. It includes numerous compound concepts joined by 'y' or 'o' (e.g., 'Formación de hemiacetales y acetales', 'carga en O y en C'). Additionally, it violated the lesson size constraint by having only 1 concept in Lesson 1 (the rule mandates 3-8 concepts). The concept titles are also often too verbose and contain parentheses with explanations rather than reading like concise glossary entries.

Model D severely violated the primary critical constraint by repeatedly using 'vs.' and 'y' to bundle concepts together (e.g., 'Reactividad relativa aldehído vs. cetona', 'Selectividad de NaBH4 vs. LiAlH4', 'Enolatos cinéticos vs. enolatos termodinámicos'). The prompt explicitly warned that if you are comparing two things, they must be split into separate concepts. It also included out-of-scope topics like the oxidation of aldehydes to carboxylic acids, crossing into a neighboring chapter's domain.

Model F also completely ignored the core negative constraint against compound concepts. It heavily relies on 'vs.' and 'y' (e.g., 'Enolatos cinéticos vs. termodinámicos', 'Adición 1,2 vs. adición 1,4'). Furthermore, it hallucinated out-of-scope topics such as general nomenclature for aldehydes and ketones, which dilutes the focus of the specific advanced chapter described in the prompt.

Muy buena cobertura del alcance del capítulo: adición nucleofílica 1,2 a carbonilos, enoles/enolatos, aldol, Claisen, Michael, anulación de Robinson y un bloque explícito de quimioselectividad/selectividad. Granularidad generalmente “micro” y lecciones de 3–8 conceptos. Buen manejo de estereoquímica (Felkin–Anh, Re/Si, Zimmerman–Traxler) y de equivalentes de enolato. Fallas menores: algunos títulos con comas (p. ej., “Hemiacetales, acetales”) no violan la regla de AND/OR pero se sienten compuestos; “Competencia de adición 1,2” dentro de Michael podría ser su propia mini-lección, pero aceptable. En general, el mejor equilibrio entre exhaustividad y organización.

Extremadamente exhaustivo y bien organizado, con mucha microgranularidad (pKa típicos, paso limitante, E/Z de enolatos, O- vs C-nucleofilia, etc.) y una unidad explícita de control de selectividad. Sin embargo, tiene violaciones claras de reglas del prompt: conceptos con “y” en títulos (p. ej., “Tautomería ceto enol y enolización”, “Estructura y reactividad de enolatos”, “Cianohidrinas y aductos de bisulfito”, “Mecanismo y reversibilidad de la aldol”) y un concepto comparativo (“Comparación de reactividad aldehído cetona”) que el prompt pedía evitar en títulos. Además, incluye contenido más “extra” de lo pedido (organocatálisis asimétrica) que puede sentirse de capítulo avanzado, aunque se puede justificar como control de selectividad. Por calidad curricular sería 9+, pero por incumplimiento de formato baja.

Sólido, conciso y bastante alineado con el capítulo: propiedades del carbonilo, adiciones (O/N/C), enolización/enolatos, aldol, Claisen, Michael y Robinson. Buena disciplina de lecciones 5–8 conceptos y títulos sin “introducción”. Debilidades: cobertura menos exhaustiva que B/E (falta reducción con hidruros, selectividad 1,2 vs 1,4 explícita, estereoquímica/facial, Mukaiyama, equivalentes tipo enol éteres silílicos). Algunas descripciones/títulos podrían ser más precisos (p. ej., “Efecto inductivo estabilizador” es vago). Aun así, cumple bien sin mucho scope creep.

Cobertura amplia (incluye Wittig/HWE, aldol, Claisen/Dieckmann, Michael/Robinson, selectividad) y estructura razonable. Pero tiene más desviaciones de alcance: bloque grande de “Reducciones y oxidaciones de carbonilos” (Swern, Jones, oxidación de aldehídos a ácidos) no está en la descripción del capítulo y encaja mejor en capítulos generales de carbonilos/redox. También varios conceptos son demasiado “paquetizados” o comparativos (“Reactividad relativa aldehído vs. cetona”, “Alquilación en carbono vs. alquilación en oxígeno”, “Enolatos cinéticos vs. enolatos termodinámicos”), contrario a reglas. Granularidad irregular (algunos conceptos muy amplios).

Buena selección de temas nucleares y progresión lógica; incluye selectividad (Felkin–Anh, quelación, auxiliares quirales) y adición conjugada. Sin embargo, varias lecciones violan el requisito de tamaño (la primera tiene 1 concepto; otras tienen 6–8 pero esa rompe fuerte). También hay muchos títulos de conceptos demasiado largos y compuestos (p. ej., “Mecanismo general de adición nucleofílica a carbonilos (ataque → tetraédrico → protonación)”, “Adición de organometálicos a carbonilos (formación de alcoholes tras protonación)”), que no son estilo “entrada de glosario”. Cobertura menos exhaustiva en detalles de Claisen/Michael/aldol comparada con A/B/E.

Incluye muchos temas relevantes (aldol, Claisen, Michael/Robinson, Wittig/HWE, enoles/enolatos), pero incumple varias reglas de estructura: una lección excede 8 conceptos ("Adiciones con Nucleófilos de Heteroátomo" tiene 12). Varias unidades incluyen contenido fuera del alcance o al menos no solicitado (Baeyer–Villiger, Cannizzaro, Tischenko, umpolung/retrosíntesis) y esto desplaza foco del capítulo. Granularidad desigual y algunos conceptos son demasiado generales (“Grupo carbonilo”, “Reacción aldol: definición y visión general”).

Estructura simple y legible con lecciones en rango 5–7 conceptos, pero es poco exhaustivo para el capítulo: casi no trata selectividad en profundidad (cinético/termodinámico apenas, nada de 1,2 vs 1,4 como unidad, poca estereoquímica de aldol), Claisen muy resumido, y omite temas relevantes comunes del capítulo (Wittig, Mukaiyama, equivalentes de enolato, control quimioselectivo). Además incluye un concepto fuera de alcance (“Alfa-halogenación de ácidos carboxílicos”), que encaja mejor en ácidos carboxílicos/derivados. En general, demasiado superficial.
